node.text:
I wrote this short story for @learningforjustice magazine last year in the rise of anti-Asian hate crimes. This week I’m so excited to share the read aloud version with y’all which was recorded in my bathtub and illustrated by the incredibly talented @janiceechang! As May 18th was the National AAPI Day Against Bullying and Hate, it couldn’t have come at a better time. Please check out organizations like @acttochange that support this work year round.
.
I hope y’all can use it as a way to discuss stereotypes, bias, and what it means to avoid being a bystander and choosing to be an accomplice or co-conspirator. I’d love to hear how it goes with your students or children!

node.text:
“Why Palestine is a feminist issue.”
.
(A reminder that I can be proudly Jewish, believe in Jewish self determination, speak out against antisemitism, be critical of the Israeli government, and center my friend’s identity and work in this conversation. Also save your thumbs the effort before sending me angry messages that I’m not mirroring your every belief.)

node.title: Dr. Randa Tawil from the Palestinian Feminist Collective

node.text:
Alex and I are book twins!! Both of our books come out next week on 5/25. Alex’s is “Equity-Centered Trauma-Informed Education,” and mine is “Start Here, Start Now: A Guide to Antibias and Antiracist Work in Your School Community.”
.
Thank you Darla and Taylor for being our ASL interpreters!

node.title: Book talk with Alex Shevrin Venet

node.text: Oh my gosh. Thank you Navjot of @saffronpress for sharing such incredible wisdom with us this evening, and educating us about the Sikh faith and the importance of acknowledging and valuing visible religious identities. Check out @saffronpress to see Navjot’s incredible picture books, and please take a few minutes to read up on the farmers protests in India. #istandwithfarmers

node.title: Sikhism and Representation with Navjot Kaur of Saffron Press

node.text: The ABAR meets religion and spirituality series continues!Thank you so much @alex.j.donovan for sharing your religious journey, and teaching us about your intersection of agnosticism and familial Celtic spirituality. It was wonderful to hear about how your faith influences your teaching folx who are new to Canada, and how you create space for your students to share their beliefs.

node.title: Alexander Donovan on Celtic Agnostic Spirituality

node.text:
OH MY GOSH. I have loved every conversation of this series and tonight’s talk with @mskass1 and @davidftelfort was mind blowing. I have never thought about abolition and liberation within the context of religion, and I so appreciate Kass for creating this partnership which has completely pushed my way of thinking.
.
Kass, thank you for sharing this part of your identity with us, and Reverend thank you for your vision of what can be possible in religious spaces.
.
In lieu of compensating today’s guests, please consider donating to Ms. E’s Go Fund Me. She’s an amazing teacher who holds DACA status and needs our support. http://gf.me/u/zb756m

node.title: Religion, Liberation, and Abolition with Kass Minor and Rev David Telfort

node.text: Thank you to the brilliant @asmahanmashrah for educating us about Islamic practices and beliefs, and how her way of life as a Muslim educator is intertwined with her social justice activism. Make sure you listen to the end to hear her suggestions about making schools inclusive for Muslim students!

node.title: Islam, Activism, and Education with Asmahan

node.text:
Maribel of @decolonizeliteracy shares her wisdom and experiences of Indigenous spirituality and how we can honor indigenous practices without appropriation.
.
Maribel is an incredible ABAR educator and consultant, so please check out her page if your school is in need of ABAR STEM support and guidance.

node.text:
The wonderful @dianedcosta (@dianemakesthings) shares her experiences growing up in Jewish culture as a person of color, and how we can work to make schools more religiously inclusive. 
.
As always, these interviews represent ONE person’s experience. Religious identities are not a monolith. 
.
CC video will be uploaded and shared via YouTube (@instagram please make it possible to CC IG Live videos to IGTV)

node.title: Judaism and Activism with Diane D’Costa

node.text:
Ace Schwarz (they/them) of @teachingoutsidethebinary talks about growing up Lutheran and the connection between faith and activism.
.
CC video: https://youtu.be/hj5imXMUnaU
.
Please consider donating to @pointofprideorg on Ace’s behalf!

node.title: Christianity and AntiBias & Antiracism with Ace Schwarz

node.text:
Thank y’all SO MUCH for joining in today’s event hosted by @auantiracismctr and moderated by the amazing @afrominimalist. If you registered but didn’t make the live event, the recording will be available (with ASL!) AND everyone can access the guidebook FOR FREE which is linked in my bio and Patreon. You can view my panel with @julyewilliams, the amazing keynote from @jasonreynolds83 , and learn more about anti racist teaching from Dr. Cheryl Holcomb-McCoy and Dr. Amanda Taylor!
.
I am so honored to be featured along with @britthawthorne @tiffanymjewell @corneliusminor and I hope the work we put in helps folx who are invested in anti racist work. Thank you @julyewilliams for your brilliance, and @cewigginton @autodidacticism of @pointmadelearning for distance-filming the digital series from all over the country during a pandemic. More thanks to @firstbookorg and @pizzahut for making this happen!

node.title: Empowering Educators: A Digital Series on Race and Racism

node.text:
A chat with @kshelton on “techquity,” anti racism in technology and education, and how educators can use tech in meaningful ways during distance schooling.
.

www.kennethshelton.net

node.title: Live with Ken Shelton on ABAR in technology and education

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Liz Kleinrock on July 24, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Yesterday I received a particularly heinous message (since the anti-CRT movement has ramped up these are more and more frequent) and a number of folx responded by asking why I didn’t share this person’s identity. A few reasons:
.
1) At the end of the day, I want to live by my values. Trolls cannot make me compromise my values. I’ve been targeted plenty online over the years, and never want to participate in the same behavior. I believe in restorative justice, which is the opposite of cancel culture.
.
2) From my perspective, when a person’s identity is shared, it becomes an attack on the individual. People blame the person, and make all sorts of assumptions about who they are, where they live, etc. Essentially, our confirmation biases go into full effect. I don’t think this is helpful or productive.
.
3) Folx ignore the systemic issues at hand and focus solely on THAT person, rather than how the person’s actions and beliefs are symptoms of some pretty fucked up stuff in our society (yes, I’m talking about white supremacy surprise surprise.)
.
To those who reached out, thank you, and I’m fine. Frankly, trash messages like this are a lot easier to delete compared to the long winded ones from liberals who need constant reassurance or feel the need to treat me like their ABAR therapist.
.
I’m sure there are plenty of people out there who will disagree with this, and that’s fine. This is a reflection of my values- no one else’s.
.
Edit: You can hold people accountable without canceling them. I don’t believe in throwing people away. To get better as a whole, we have to believe in people’s ability to evolve and change for the better. Call me an idealist but 🤷🏻‍♀️

node.text:
This has been a major mood in my circle lately. Frankly I’m tired and angry of well intentioned white folx who refuse to understand or recognize their part in upholding inequitable systems and practices because they refuse to acknowledge and relinquish power and control. (I’M LOOKING AT YOU WHITE PRINCIPALS AND EDUCATION LEADERS WORKING IN BIPOC COMMUNITIES WHO CONTINUE TO CENTER THEMSELVES AND THEIR COMFORT.)
.
IDGAF that you brought in guest speakers for cultural heritage months, or that you started an antiracist book club. To me, it comes down to WHO HAS THE LAST WORD? If BIPOC community members speak up about their wants and needs and one/a small group of white folx have the ability to overrule, your DEI initiatives are bullshit.
.
Edit: Holy shit. I posted this less than an hour ago and already have numerous DMs saying “not all white school leaders” and others demanding that I tell them how to fix this. Fuck, if I knew the catch all solution, I’d tell you. This energy is why BIPOC are being driven off social media. If this post pissed you off, you’re probably part of the problem.

node.text:
It’s almost my book’s 2 month anniversary and it still feels surreal. What’s brought me back to reality is seeing how folx are using it, learning, and processing. I almost cried when I saw folx already using it to guide PD (slide 2.)
.
To everyone who’s shared my book on social media, please know how much I love and appreciate y’all. Every story post that has tagged the book is saved in my profile highlights because I never want to forget how this feels.
.
This quote has been reshared a bit, and I can’t tell you how awesome and bizarre it is to see your work quoted and cited. If you’ve read/are currently reading my book, I’d love it if you’d drop your favorite quote or something you’ve learned or thought about in the comments! Thank y’all again so much!

node.text:
Seems so simple right? 🤦🏻‍♀️
.
I am fully embracing summer by not doing much work this month, but I couldn’t pass up the #RESI2021 conference (as a participant!) with such amazing sessions and the brilliant @nikolehannahjones keynoting on day one. Appreciated her insight on the development of the 1619 Project so much, as well as her response to the anti-CRT movement. So excited to welcome her to DC!!

BY ELIZABETH KLEINROCK JULY 6, 2021'.

node.text:
Know what really grinds my gears? When adults erase students and act like they don’t have a say in their own education. With all of the mess around critical race theory, it’s disappointing but not surprising that students have not been asked for their take on the matter.
.
I’m proud to share this article with @learningforjustice that I *barely* wrote and features the perspectives of some of my former students from over the years. To those who shared their thoughts, y’all are incredible and the most amazing reminder of why I love what I do.
.
If you’re a student, parent, caregiver, or educator who lives in a state or district that’s coming out strong against teaching about racism and complete US history, now is a great time to reach out to your school or district and let them know the importance of teaching these issues and that they have your full support.
.
For full article, check my IG story or the @learningforjustice website.

May be an image of text that says 'As these laws will touch millions of our nation'. youth, I wondered what my students thought about this ongoing battle over teaching about race, racism and U.S. history The following responses were collected from a group of my current and former students, ranging from fifth to ninth grades. (All students who are quoted volunteered to participate and gave permission for their words to be used anonymously.)'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'LEARNING FOR JUSTICE Question: Right now, many teachers, parents and politicians are trying to pass laws to make it illegal for schools to teach about race, racism, gender and privilege, among other social justice-related topics. Some even call teaching about these issues brainwashing and believe it will cause people to be more divided. Do you agree or disagree? Why?'.
Photo by Liz Kleinrock on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'think it is so important to learn about social justice in school, if children aren't earning this then we will be going back in time. Separation and division will be more extreme as if we are to teach our generation what we have done wrong so they know what to do better. If we are ever actually looking for a future of equality then we must properly teach our future and present. (ninth grade)'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Learning about race and racism is a very sensitive topic, but far from brainwashing. If people don't start to learn, there really won't be any progress, everyone will just keep hating everyone who's ditterent. It's only a sensitive topic because people are uncomfortable talking about it, and that's not right. In the future if people start to learn about equality, hopefully this topic will just be normal. (seventh grade)'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'think that it is even more brainwashing to deny that there are hate crimes happening everywhere. This world has awful things but we can absolutely change the way that we treat each other. (ninth grade)'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Rather than center our own, adult perspectives, we cannot forget that our education system exists to serve our students. It's our responsibility to equip them with the tools to learn from mistakes of the past and build a better future. Lessons that as tackle issues my students mentioned-suc gender-based pay disparities, the ugly parts of U.S. history such as enslavement, and how racism permeates and manifests in our society-invite society young learners to view our nation holistically and draw their own conclusions.'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Those of us who teach about identity and history within the context of the United States do so because we care about the future of this country and are investing in its healing from past and present trauma. We can't change the past. But when we as educators recognize that we have the power to create a more fair and inclusive future, we have a responsibility to do'.

node.text:
Tomorrow (July 4th) is my birthday. Typically I’d post something about the hypocrisy of Independence Day commemorating a bunch of white guys who enslaved Black folx and murdered Indigenous communities, but there’s plenty of folx sharing all that info and for my birthday I want to put my energy into healing.
.
For my birthday fundraiser, I’m asking y’all to donate to @nabshc. From their website: “NABS was created to develop and implement a national strategy that increases public awareness and cultivates healing for the profound trauma experienced by individuals, families, communities, American Indian and Alaska Native Nations resulting from the U.S. adoption and implementation of the Boarding School Policy of 1869.” This organization has a ton of research and information on US Indigenous boarding schools, curriculum for educators, and healing resources for Indigenous communities.
.
If you’re financially able, please give what you can. Thank you!

node.text:
My friend @mr_lyon_4th had some homophobic comments on his recent post, so here’s a reminder that it’s inaccurate and bigoted to use kids as an excuse for your ignorance. When I hear an adult say, “Children can’t learn about LGBTQ+ people and issues,” what I really hear is “I AM NOT WILLING to learn about LGBTQ+ people and issues.”
.
Kids are more than capable. Don’t insult kids by projecting your BS on them. Also stop weaponizing your religion to justify your bigotry. That shit is boring AF. Also stop making this entire conversation about sex. That’s a you thing, not an us thing.
.
Y’all already know, but there’s no room for homophobia or transphobia in my space, so if you’re itching to say some nonsense, keep your mess to yourself.
.
Thanks @mrwilly_prek @soyouwanttotalkabout for the last 3 slides!

My school went back to virtual for the last two weeks, and it feels like the year just trickled off. No end of the year parties, many kids stopped coming in the last week. I'm glad school over, but now feel empty. 2:52 PM 6/24/21 Twitter for iPhone'.

node.text: Holding multiple truths: This year was pretty awful for many reasons. I hope to never teach kids full time on Zoom again. But even though it was rough, it feels strange and empty to not say goodbye to students face to face, and not have EOY celebrations. I’m used to doing a ton of reflection and group activities and giving out paper plate awards tailored to each student. Ending the year virtually feels so abrupt and anticlimactic.

node.text: Why yes, this is what I spent time making today. 😒🤦🏻‍♀️

Being an athlete was a huge part of my childhood identity. I played soccer starting in early elementary school, and moved on to track, volleyball, and ultimate frisbee later in middle and high school. As a cisgender girl, I had no issues finding sports teams that welcomed and included me.
💙
Our trans children deserve full access to participating in sports, and all the amazing aspects of being an athlete starting from a young age. I support trans athletes, and if you do too, please share the following slides that have been so generously created by @pinkmantaray at pinkmantaray.com/lettranskidsplay.
🤍
Thank you @pinkmantaray for organizing this and using your platform to call others into the movement and educate our community!
💗
PS- Absolutely not here to debate anyone’s identity or humanity. Any transphobic BS will get you blocked immediately.

node.text:
Proud and grateful to share this follow up collaboration with @soyouwanttotalkabout on talking to kids about racism
💛
Be sure to check the first series on “Talking to Kids About Race!”

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Liz Kleinrock on June 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'so YOU WANT TO TALK ABOUT Talking to Kids About Racism'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on June 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Racism is often explained as, "People of color are treated unfairly because of the color of their skin." However, this is inaccurate and misleading. People of color are treated unfairly because of white supremacy. @SOYOUWANTTOTALKABOUT @TEACHANDTRANSFORM'.
Photo by Liz Kleinrock on June 09, 2021. May be an image of text.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on June 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Be open and honest about your own journey. Based on your comfort level and hat you know about your child, tell them if you grew up experiencing or observing racism, and how those experiences continue to impact you. Be clear about why you' re teaching and talking with them about racism, and why it's important. @SOYOUWANTTOTALKABOUT @TEACHANDTRANSFORM'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on June 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Approach your child from a place of curiosity. Ask them questions like, "Have you ever heard the word 'racist' before? Can you tell me what means?" Your child's response will give you an idea of where to begin. For example, fyour child gives response similar to, "People of color are treated unfairly because of the color of their skin, (see slide 2) take this as an opportunity to correct any misconceptions. @SOYOUWANTTOTALKABOUT @TEACHANDTRANSFORM'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on June 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Start with basic, foundational concepts. Does your child know the difference between something beingfair, and something being equal? Discuss the importance of fairness (people getting what they need), and when it's important to emphasize equality (people getting the same thing). These concepts are foundational to children understanding the context of concepts like segregation, affirmative action, and Black Lives Matter. @SOYOUWANTTOTALKABOUT @TEACHANDTRANSFORM'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on June 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Talk about systems of power. Ask your child, "What does it mean for a person or group to have power? How does person or group gain power? How can someone in position of power use it to either help or harm others?" This conversation can be wav to bridge the idea of race as social construct (see"So (see you want talk kids about race' post), and why racial categories were created. Also, remind your child that race is NOT rooted in biology. With older children, this can also be springboard to differentiate between different types of racism. @SOYOUWANTTOTALKABOUT @TEACHANDTRANSFORM'.
Photo by Liz Kleinrock on June 09, 2021. May be an image of text.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on June 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Brainstorm and discuss actionable steps to being antiracist (this includes you and your child!) Practice interrupting and correcting your child's biases and misconceptions. fyour child makes a problematic comment, try these responses: "I'm curious about what you just said. Can you explain what you mean?" "There some history behind that word that you might not know about. "Do you think you d say that if person of that identity was listening?" Discuss similar strategies with your child and how they can interrupt and educate their peers at school or in social settings. @SOYOUWANTTOTALKABOUT @TEACHANDTRANSFORM'.

Photo by Liz Kleinrock on June 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Resources: The Conscious Kid EmbraceRace.org LearningForJustice.org Stamped (For Kids) by Jason Reyn Reynolds & Ibram X, Kendi, adapted by Sonja Cherry Paul Anti bias Education for Young Children and Ourselves by Catherine M. Goins, Julie Olsen Edwards, and Louise Derman Spark @SOYOUWANTTOTALKABOUT @TEACHANDTRANSFORM'.
